This
On
Week
List
Fiction
WINTER SOLSTICE, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Thomas Dunne/ St. Martin's, $27.95.) As Christmas approaches, five lost souls in the north of Scotland discover the healing power of love.
DUST TO DUST, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $25.95.) Two Minneapolis police officers investigate the suspicious death of an Internal Affairs cop.
NOT A DAY GOES BY, by E. Lynn Harris. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The tumultuous romance between a football player turned sports agent and an up-and-coming Broadway star.
THE HOUSE ON HOPE STREET, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A woman with five children must cope with the loss of her husband, who dies on Christmas Day.
OMERTA, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $25.95.) An F.B.I. agent targets a recently retired Mafia don who has tried to shield his three grown children from the family business.
MR. PERFECT, by Linda Howard. (Pocket Books, $24.95.) After four women compile a list of the attributes an ideal man would possess, one of them is murdered.
RIPTIDE, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam, $23.95.) The senior speechwriter for the governor of New York flees a stalker as well as the police after her boss is shot.
PURPLE CANE ROAD, by James Lee Burke. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Dave Robicheaux, a Louisiana sheriff's deputy, searches for his mother's killers.
NORA, Nora, by Anne Rivers Siddons. (HarperCollins, $25.) An outsider who harbors a secret from her past shakes up the quiet town of Lytton, Ga.
THE INDWELLING, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) Volume 7 in a series about true believers who confront the Antichrist after the rapture of the saved. (+)
THE BRETHREN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) Three former judges, doing time at a federal prison in Florida, concoct a mail scam that goes awry.
THE RIVER KING, by Alice Hoffman. (Putnam, $23.95.) A police officer in a small Massachusetts town investigates the supposed suicide of a freshman at the local prep school.
HEARTBREAKER, by Julie Garwood. (Pocket Books, $24.95.) An F.B.I. agent tries to prevent his best friend's sister from being killed by a deranged fiend.
DEADLY DeCISIONS, by Kathy Reichs. (Scribner, $25.) When a girl is shot dead in Montreal, a forensic anthropologist finds herself enmeshed in the world of outlaw motorcycle gangs.
*HOT SIX, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) A New Jersey bounty hunter searches for her mentor, who is the No. 1 suspect in the killing of an arms dealer's son.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam, $24.95.) A memoir by the Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
LIFE ON THE OTHER SIDE, by Sylvia Browne with Lindsay Harrison. (Dutton, $23.95.) A guided tour of the afterlife, by a ''working psychic.''
AMERICAN RHAPSODY, by Joe Eszterhas. (Knopf, $25.95.) The Lewinsky affair and Hollywood, as seen by the man who wrote ''Basic Instinct'' and ''Showgirls.''
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam, $24.95.) The story of the six men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima, by the son of one of them.
ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A collection of autobiographical comic essays by the author of ''Naked.''
THE DAY JOHN DIED, by Christopher Andersen. (Morrow, $26.) The events leading up to the plane crash that killed John F. Kennedy Jr., Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and Lauren Bessette.
*IN THE HEART OF THE SEA, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $24.95.) An account of the whaleship Essex, whose disastrous fate in the early 19th century would inspire Herman Melville.
IN A SUNBURNED COUNTRY, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $25.) The author of ''A Walk in the Woods'' reports on his travels through Australia.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War II.
KITCHEN CONFIDENTIAL, by Anthony Bourdain. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) A memoir-expose by the executive chef at Brasserie Les Halles in New York.
*FROM DAWN TO DECADENCE, by Jacques Barzun. (HarperCollins, $36.) A survey of 500 years of Western cultural life, from 1500 to the present.
*BOBOS IN PARADISE, by David Brooks. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A work of ''comic sociology'' that examines the rise of the bourgeois bohemians who constitute the new upper class.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
PAPAL SIN, by Garry Wills. (Doubleday, $25.) A chronicle of what the author sees as the evasions and distortions of the Vatican over the past two centuries.

This
On
Week
List
Children's Books
HARRY POTTER AND THE GOBLET OF FIRE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/ Scholastic, $25.95.) A British boy takes part in a series of contests against other aspiring wizards. (Ages 10 and up)
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy finds trouble on his return to a witchcraft school. (Ages 10 and up)
HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is threatened. (Ages 10 and up)
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy attends a school for witchcraft. (Ages 10 and up)
BACKSTREET BOYS: The Official Book, by Andre Csillag with the Backstreet Boys. (Delacorte, $14.95.) A photographic scrapbook. (All ages)
BOBBI BROWN TEENAGE BEAUTY, by Bobbi Brown and Annemarie Iverson. (Cliff Street/HarperCollins, $25.) Beauty tips. (Ages 13 to 19)
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! written and illustrated by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $17.) Finding your way through life. (Ages 8 and up)
HOW DO DINOSAURS SAY GOOD NIGHT? by Jane Yolen. Illustrated by Mark Teague. (Blue Sky/Scholastic, $15.95.) It's bedtime for dinosaur children. (Ages 3 to 8)
WEMBERLY WORRIED, written and illustrated by Kevin Henkes. (Greenwillow, $15.95.) A mouse fears her first day of school. (Ages 4 to 8)
THE LITTLE PRINCE, written and illustrated by Antoine de Saint-Exupery. Translated by Richard Howard. (Harcourt, $18.) A new version of the French classic. (All ages)
ELOISE'S GUIDE TO LIFE, by Kay Thompson. Illustrated by Hilary Knight. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) How to eat, dress, behave, travel and ''stay 6 forever.'' (All ages)
BUD, NOT BUDDY, by Christopher Paul Curtis. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A 10-year-old boy sets out to find the father he's never seen. (Ages 8 to 12)
THE AUSTERE ACADEMY, by Lemony Snicket. (HarperCollins, $8.95.) The fifth book in a series about the Baudelaire siblings, who find misfortune everywhere. (Ages 10 and up)
THOMAS AND THE MAGIC RAILROAD, by Britt Allcroft. Illustrated by Tommy Stubbs. (Random House, $10.99.) A little blue engine must cope with evil Diesel 10. (Ages 4 to 8)
OLYMPIC SUMMER GAMES 2000, by Meredith Costain. (Puffin, $3.99.) A guide to the Olympic Games in Sydney, Australia. (Ages 9 to 12)
*JOSEPH HAD A LITTLE OVERCOAT, written and illustrated by Simms Taback. (Viking, $15.99.) A man transforms his worn-out coat into smaller garments. (Ages 5 to 9)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Aug. 5, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children's titles.
